The calculator.py uses the @property decorator, which we really didn't talk about, but makes a method look like an attribute. Both follow the convention that attributes and methods starting with _ are for internal use only.

I added the solutions to <https://github.com/zipfian/solns-python-fundamentals-seattle-4>, both the one for the exercise as described (calculator.py) and mine (rpn.py). I'd recommend starting with mine since all of you (other than Colin) were following that approach, and I think it's easier to follow. You can run either from the terminal (e.g. 'python rpn.py').
On my way...

Got it. I tried `a = def_tip` because I couldn't get `self.a = def_tip` to work either, but I think that's because I was trying to use `self.a` as a default value for an argument. Thanks for the help!

Second, in `add_bill`, I believe the accepted way to accomplish what you’re after is this

```
def add_bill(self, bill_value, tip_rate=None):
    if tip_rate is None:
        tip_rate = self.default_tip_rate
    self.bills.append((bill_value, tip_rate))
```

First, you need to assign to `self.a` if you want to remember the tip rate you pass into `__init__`.  The way you’ve got it now, the varaible `a` is assigned in `__init__`, but that value will be lost forever after `__init__` finished its job.

I’d write that part like this:

```
def __init__(self, default_tip_rate=0.18):
    self.default_tip_rate = default_tip_rate
    self.bills = []
```

messages.text:
Sorry, I realized I never answered this. The problem is that the first part of the list comprehension has to be an "expression" which basically means it has some value (like a+b), and that sum+=x isn't an expression.

In this case, it's easy to use the sum() function.
gotcha. len(member.questions_asked) should work in the list comprehension then
questions_asked is actually supposed to be a list I think

messages.text: yeah I just went with:

<@U407DC9LL|brendan.dorsey> uploaded a file: <https://gstudents.slack.com/files/brendan.dorsey/F4ETZ7JV6/-.py|Untitled> and commented: Colin I think this is how you'd make that work with list comprehension. I think the list comprehension can only be used to build a list, which you can then pass into sum() to get the result. I think you'd have to use a for loop to increment a variable without building a list.

initial_comment.comment: Colin I think this is how you'd make that work with list comprehension. I think the list comprehension can only be used to build a list, which you can then pass into sum() to get the result. I think you'd have to use a for loop to increment a variable without building a list.

messages.text: <@U1Y8Q30LE|jack> uploaded a file: <https://gstudents.slack.com/files/jack/F4DTUC5T3/-.txt|Untitled> and commented: Here's the class we did, plus some other methods you might want to try implementing. If you're interested, the order (easiest to hardest) is probably __sub__, __len__, __neg__, __rmul__, __mul__ (if you allow Polynomial * Polynomial), integral. Improving __str__ is pretty difficult if you try to handle everything.

If you're interested, the order (easiest to hardest) is probably __sub__, __len__, __neg__, __rmul__, __mul__ (if you allow Polynomial * Polynomial), integral. Improving __str__ is pretty difficult if you try to handle everything.

I have a question about the first assignment question from part 2 Advanced Practice: 
"1. Write a function that figures out whether or not we have any beers left on our wall. It should take in a number, and then print 'No beers left' if we are at the end (i.e. there are `0` beers left) or 'Beers left!' if we are not at the end (i.e. there are not `0` beers left). "

Is this really just asking for a function that returns two different strings based on whether or not n > 0 ?

Your approach worked in your first case 'cause there are an even number of characters and it didn't include the last one. It won't work with an odd number.

Hi Victor - I think your problem is that the range should be `range (1, len('abcd'),  2)` (without the +1). If the string is length 4, then the index of the last character is 3, so you want the range to go to 3, so the second argument to range() should be 4 (i.e., len('abce').

For Part 2 #4 in the Practice with String assignment, I have for x in  range (1, len(abcd)+1,  2), with abcd = list(abc).  With longer strings, this returns an error  "list index out of range".  I've tried Google and the answers were not as clear as I'd like.  Any thoughts?

Yup. the isdigit() method returns True if a string only has digits (and is at least one character) and False otherwise. Usually you think of code going through a loop multiple times, but here it won't even execute the loop once in the normal case (when the useer enters an integer).
Is it just to ensure that the user input is an integer?
